IncidentInformation:
The Water Boards is performing an ambient monitoring study in coordination with the SWAMP Bioassessment Reference Condition Monitoring Program to collect toxic algal samples in wadeable streams. In 2021, samples will be collected twice at each monitoring station in areas with absent or minimal human disturbance in coordination with California Department of Fish and Wildlife. This study is to better characterize toxic algal mat presence throughout the state of California. The lab results and recommendations for this site is below.
.
10/1/2021: two samples were collected on 9/20. The first sample had anatoxin-a present at 3.76 ng/g dry weight and microcystins at 700 ng/g dry weight. The second sample had anatoxin-a present at 6.63 ng/g dry weight and microcystins at 2,285 ng/g dry weight. Microcystins exceeded the Office of Environmental Health and Hazard Assessment acute action level for dogs for crusts and mats. Because harmful algal mats are present, a toxic algae alert is recommended.

WaterBodyName: Driftwood Bay, cove in between driftwood and monterey
IncidentInformation: 10/4/21: Reporting party observed that it  looked like  antifreeze was floating in the water. The floating subsance was reported to be neon green and the area to smell like algae on a hot day. Caution advisory recommended.

IncidentInformation:
11/3/2021: Sample was collected on 10/19. Sample was non-detect for cyanotoxins. No advisory recommended. 

10/6/21: Samples were taken on 9/28 and cyanobacteria were present, but no genes were present that have the ability to produce toxins.

The Water Boards is performing an ambient monitoring study in coordination with the SWAMP Bioassessment Reference Condition Monitoring Program to collect toxic algal samples in wadeable streams. In 2021, samples will be collected twice at each monitoring station in areas with absent or minimal human disturbance in coordination with California Department of Fish and Wildlife. This study is to better characterize toxic algal mat presence throughout the state of California. The lab results and recommendations for this site is below.
.
10/7/2021: sample was taken on 9/27. Lab analysis had anatoxin-a present at 10.8 ng/g dry weight, microcystins at 32.5 ng/g dry weight, and saxitoxin at 88.2 ng/g dry weight. Because cyanotoxins were present in the mats, a toxic algae alert is recommended.

The Water Boards is performing an ambient monitoring study in coordination with the SWAMP Bioassessment Reference Condition Monitoring Program to collect toxic algal samples in wadeable streams. In 2021, samples will be collected twice at each monitoring station in areas with absent or minimal human disturbance in coordination with California Department of Fish and Wildlife. This study is to better characterize toxic algal mat presence throughout the state of California. The lab results and recommendations for this site is below.

10/7/2021: sample collected on 9/28. Anatoxin-a present at 11.12 ng/g dry weight. Because cyanotoxins were present in the mats, a toxic algae alert is recommended.

The Water Boards is performing an ambient monitoring study in coordination with the SWAMP Bioassessment Reference Condition Monitoring Program to collect toxic algal samples in wadeable streams. In 2021, samples will be collected twice at each monitoring station in areas with absent or minimal human disturbance in coordination with California Department of Fish and Wildlife. This study is to better characterize toxic algal mat presence throughout the state of California. The lab results and recommendations for this site is below.

10/7/2021: Sample was collected on 9/29. Cyanotoxins were present with anatoxin-a at 18.12 ng/g dry weight, cylindrospermopsin at 5.29 ng/g dry weight, microcystins at 39.15 ng/g dry weight, and saxitoxin at 3.19 ng/g dry weight. Because cyanotoxins were present in the mat, a toxic algae alert is recommended.

12/31/2021: sample was collected on 12/22. Anatoxin-a detected at 0.18 ug/L. Caution advisory recommended. 

12/9/21: Samples were taken on 12/2/21 and the results indicate that no toxins are present. Caution is still advised due to the detection of a cyanobacteria species that has the ability to produce the toxin microcystin, the presence of algae on the beach, and the high level of recreational use by visitors and potentially dogs. 

11/3/2021: Regional Water Board staff collected a sample on 10/19. Anatoxin-a was detected at 0.17 ug/L. Caution advisory recommended. 

10/14/2021: Regional Water Board staff collected a sample on 10/7. Anatoxin-a was detected at 0.23 ug/L. Caution advisory recommended.
10/14/2021: Regional Water Board staff collected a sample on 10/7. qPCR showed non-detect for anatoxin-a, cylindorspermopsin, microcystins, and saxitoxin. No advisory.
10/14/2021: Regional Water Board staff collected a sample on 10/7. For microscopy, the sample contained a low amount of eukaryotic algae and no cyanobacteria was observed. No advisory.
10/18/21: Central Valley Waterboard staff collected a sample on 10/7. Results showed microcystin levels at 0.30 ug/L. No advisory recommended at this time.

10/25/2021: A follow-up site visit confirmed that heavy rains had dissipated the bloom that was observed on 10/15/2021. No posting is recommended at this time. 

10/23/2021: North Coast Regional Water Board received a report and pictures of a likely cyanobacterial bloom that was observed on 10/15/2021. The Water Board recommended posting signs if the bloom was still present following heavy rains.
OfficialWaterBodyName: Mill Creek Pond, near Dam Fence

WaterBodyName: San Diego River east of Mast Park
IncidentInformation:
11/5/2021: Lab results of water grab received today. No toxins were detected. City of Santee will remove the Caution sign.

11/1/2021: No obvious bloom. Toxin water grab collected today. Results will be updated with lab data.
OfficialWaterBodyName: San Diego River east of Mast Park

WaterBodyName: Lake in Greenhill Gated estates - near Laguna and Lakeshore.  South ave 26 and east 99
IncidentInformation: 11/24/21: Golf Course staff sampled this area on 11/17. Results showed that the Microcystin concentration was 2,206.9 ug/L, the Cylindrospermopsin concentration was 0.16 ug/L and the Saxitoxin concentration was 0.10 ug/L. Danger advisory recommended.
OfficialWaterBodyName: Lake in Greenhill Gated Estates near Laguna Dr. and Lakeshore Dr.

WaterBodyName: Merced River at top of Nevada Falls
IncidentInformation: 11/9/2021: Report submitted by National Park Service including observations of cyanobacteria mats in Merced River near Nevada Falls on 10/21 and water testing results. Report also includes report of illnesses that is under investigation by the Interagency Illness Workgroup. No advisory has been posted by National Park since significant flushing of the river by storms occurred after sampling. This record will be updated as data is available.
OfficialWaterBodyName: Merced River at top of Nevada Falls

IncidentInformation: 11/15/2021: Water Boards received a report of a bloom in the cyanobacteria bloom observed on 11/8/21. The bloom was reported to cover the majority of the western basin of Lake Almanor. Caution advisory recommended at this time.

WaterBodyName: Topaz Lake - Campground and Boat Ramp
IncidentInformation:
The sample taken on 11/16/21 contained cyanobacteria, but did not have genes present that have the ability to produce toxins.

11/17/21: Water board staff inspected Topaz Lake on 11/16/21, and a large bloom appears to be located on the Nevada side of the lake along the area called the Topaz Recreation area. Caution is advised until lab results return.
OfficialWaterBodyName: Topaz Lake Campground and Boat Ramp

IncidentInformation:
12/13/21: Lab results from three samples taken on 12/6/21 indicate no toxins present. Caution will remain in place until the illness workgroup has completed the investigation. 

12/6/21: Visual indicators of a bloom are not present, but a dog has been reported to become ill after drinking water from the lake. Samples have been taken, and results are pending. Out of an abundance of caution signs have been posted.
OfficialWaterBodyName: Lake Baron - Disk Golf Course Hole 9

IncidentInformation: 12/08/2021: The County of San Luis Obispo Parks and Recreation Department conducts regular monitoring at Lopez Lake. Recent monitoring data from submerged intakes did not detect cyanobacteria by microscope. No monitoring of the water surface was conducted.

East Bay Regional Park District conducts routine cyanobacteria bloom monitoring at this lake or shoreline location. For more info, go to: https://www.ebparks.org/about/stewardship/water/cyanobacteria_(blue_green_algae)_updates.htm

Routine monitoring results are provided below:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On 4/4/22, no cyanobacteria were observed at the swim beach or at the south end of the lake. A sample from the south end was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.15 ppb.
On 3/22/22, no cyanobacteria were observed at the swim beach or at the northwest dock.
On 3/15/22, very few small specks of Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the northwest dock. A sample from the northwest dock was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.32 ppb. 
On 3/9/22, two small specks of Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the northwest dock. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.1ppb. 

On 3/1/22, no cyanobacteria were observed at the northwest dock. 

On 2/23/22, no cyanobacteria were observed at the swim beach or in Temescal Creek.

On 2/15/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the northwest dock. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. 

On 2/8/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the northwest dock. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. 

On 1/24/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the swim beach nor at the northwest dock. 

On 1/10/22 and 1/11/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the swim beach or northwest dock

On 12/27/21, this weeks storms stirred up sediment around the lake, making cyanobacteria observation difficult. No visible cyanobacteria were observed at the Northwest Dock. 
On 11/22/21, the lake was still brown and murky. No visible cyanobacteria were observed at the northwest dock.

East Bay Regional Park District conducts routine cyanobacteria bloom monitoring at this lake or shoreline location. This lake is currently closed to swimming due to Shelter in Place mandate. For more info, go to: https://www.ebparks.org/about/stewardship/water/cyanobacteria_(blue_green_algae)_updates.htm

Routine monitoring results are provided below:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On 4/6/22, grass-clipping-like clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.09ppb. A washed up green band of cyanobacteria and the same clumps and specks were observed suspended in the water column at the swim beach.

On 3/29/22, grass-clipping-like specks and small specks of Aphanizomenon-type and specks of Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column throughout the lake. A turquoise band was observed along the shoreline at the swim beach, where Dolichospermum-type, Microcystis-type, Aphanizomenon-type, and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in dense accumulations in the water column. A sample from the south end of the swim beach was tested for Microcystins, using an Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in greater than 10 ppb.
Dense accumulations of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, Microcystis-type, and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed at Lago Los Osos. A sample from Lago Los Osos was tested for Microcystins, using an Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in greater than 10 ppb. Small clumps of Dolichospermum-type and Aphanizomenon-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at Shinn Pond.


On 3/23/22, grass-clipping-like specks and small clumps of Aphanizomenon-type and specks of Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. 
On 3/15/22, teal and green surface level swirls and suspended clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, Microcystis-type, and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed at the boat launch. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in greater than 50 ppb. Danger/closure advisory signage has been placed around Horseshoe Lake. Various sized suspended clumps of Aphanizomenon-type and mats of scum with Planktothrix-type cyanobacteria were observed in the water column at Lago Los Osos. A sample from Lago Los Osos was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 12.95 ppb. Surface level green swirls and suspended specks of Aphanizomenon-type, Woronichinia-type, and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed in the water column at Shinn Pond. The same visual conditions were observed at Grau pond. A sample from Shinn Pond was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.14 ppb. 

On 3/7/22, grass-clipping-like specks of Aphanizomenon-type cyanobacteria with smaller specks of Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed at the swim beach. Various sized clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a 1.59 ppb. Caution advisory signage has been placed around Horseshoe Lake. Fine specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at Shinn Pond. A sample from Shinn Pond was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. No cyanobacteria were observed at Grau Pond.

On 2/28/22, various sized clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. Green surface level swirls and various sized clumps of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at Lago Los Osos. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. A sample from Lago Los Osos was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.69 ppb.

On 2/14/22, small clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. Green surface level swirls and densely suspended specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at Lago Los Osos. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.36 ppb. A sample from Lago Los Osos was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 13.32 ppb. Danger signage has been posted around Lago Los Osos.

On 2/7/22, clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. Small clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at Lago Los Osos. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.49 ppb. A sample from Lago Los Osos was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.13 ppb. 

On 2/1/22, clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. Some small clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at Lago Los Osos. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.19 ppb. A sample from Lago Los Osos was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 3.04 ppb. Caution advisory signage has been placed around Lago Los Osos.

On 1/26/22, scum, clumps, and specks of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. Some small clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at Lago Los Osos. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.35 ppb. A sample from Lago Los Osos was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect.

On 1/10/22, suspended clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed at the boat launch and throughout the east and west branches of Horseshoe Lake. Small grass-clipping-like specks of Aphanizomenon-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at Lago Los Osos. No visible cyanobacteria were observed at Shinn or Grau ponds. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kits, resulting in a non-detect.

On 1/3/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the swim beach, Lago Los Osos, Grau Pond, or Shinn Pond. Suspended clumps and surface level swirls of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed accumulating around the boat launch and surrounding shore. Samples from the boat launch and Shinn Pond were tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kits, resulting in non-detects.

On 12/28/21, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the swim beach or boat launch.

East Bay Regional Park District conducts routine cyanobacteria bloom monitoring at this lake or shoreline location. For more info, go to: https://www.ebparks.org/about/stewardship/water/cyanobacteria_(blue_green_algae)_updates.htm
Routine monitoring results are provided below:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On 4/4/22, specks and a few clumps of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using an Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.76 ppb. Benthic mats of Microcoleus-type and Oscillatoria-type or Planktothrix-type cyanobacteria were observed at the east swim beach. Samples were also taken from the intake at drinking water plant and from the Marina restrooms, neither of which had any visible cyanobacteria. A sample of raw water from the intake was tested for Microcystins, using an Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. A sample of finished drinking water from the Marina restrooms was tested for Microcystins, using an Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. 

On 3/29/22, various sized clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using an Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in a non-detect. Samples were also taken from the intake at drinking water plant and from the Marina restrooms, neither of which had any visible cyanobacteria. A sample of raw water from the intake was tested for Microcystins, using an Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in a non-detect. A sample of finished drinking water from the Marina restrooms was tested for Microcystins, using an Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in a non-detect. 

On 3/22/22, various sized clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.8 ppb. Samples were also taken from the clarifier at the drinking water plant and from Building 13, neither of which had any visible cyanobacteria. A sample of raw water from the clarifier was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.04 ppb. A sample of finished drinking water from Building 13 was tested for Microcystins, resulting in 0.09 ppb. Both the drinking water results are well below Californias state advisory levels for Microcystins in finished drinking water of 0.3 ppb

On 3/15/22, small clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.22 ppb.

On 3/7/22, clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.88ppb. Patches of benthic Planktothrix-type, Oscillatoria-type, and Aphanizomenon-type cyanobacteria were observed adhered to the substrate at the east beach. A sample from the east beach was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect.

On 3/1/22, mats of scum, specks and various sized clumps of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. The same cyanobacteria types were observed at the east and west swim beaches. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 1.98ppb. 

On 2/22/22, dispersed specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. 

On 2/17/22, specks and small clumps of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in a non-detect. 

On 2/7/22, specks and small clumps of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. Two samples were taken from the boat launch: one at an area with a high density of cyanobacteria, and another adjacent sample at an area with a low density of cyanobacteria. The high density sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.32 ppb. The low density sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. A sample of raw water from the clarifier at the drinking water plant was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in a non-detect. A sample of finished drinking water from Building 13 was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in a non-detect. Advisory signage has been downgraded to Caution around the lake.

On 2/2/22, high winds made cyanobacteria observation difficult. Small clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. On 2/3/22, the wind had calmed and cyanobacteria observation was much easier. Specks and quarter-sized clumps of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed at the boat launch. Two samples were taken from the boat launch: one at an area with a high density of cyanobacteria, and another adjacent sample at an area with a low density of cyanobacteria. The high density sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 3.4 ppb. The low density sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. A sample of finished drinking water from Building 13 was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in a non-detect.

On 1/27/22, scum, large clumps, and specks of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. Less dense accumulations of the same cyanobacteria types were observed at the east and west swim beach. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.40 ppb. A sample from the raw water coming into the drinking water plant was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.15 ppb. A sample of finished drinking water from Building 13 was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect.

On 1/18/22, large clumps and specks of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. Less dense accumulations of the same cyanobacteria types were observed at the west swim beach. The same cyanobacteria types in thicker accumulations were observed at the east beach, with the addition of a thick band of turquoise colored cyanobacteria washed up along the shore. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 3.36ppb. A sample from the east beach was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in greater than 50ppb.

On 1/11/22, large clumps, some as big as a dollar bill, and specks of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the boat launch. Some turquoise and white discolorations were observed within the cyanobacteria colonies as well. The same visual conditions were observed at both the marina and the visitor center dock. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Test Strip Kits, resulting in greater than 10ppb.

IncidentInformation:
East Bay Regional Park District conducts routine cyanobacteria bloom monitoring at this lake or shoreline location. For more info, go to: https://www.ebparks.org/about/stewardship/water/cyanobacteria_(blue_green_algae)_updates.htm

Routine monitoring results are provided below:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On 4/5/22, no cyanobacteria were observed at the popular Arroyo dog access area. On 4/5/22, no cyanobacteria were observed at the boat launch.

On 3/21/22, a few strands of Aphanizomenon-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the popular dog area. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.06 ppb. On 3/21/22, no cyanobacteria were observed throughout the lake from the boat launch to the substrate sampler buoy.
On 3/15/22, no cyanobacteria were observed at the popular dog area in Arroyo. No cyanobacteria were observed at the boat launch in the lake.

Shadow Cliffs lake:  no cyanobacteria were observed at the boat launch.

On 3/1/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the popular dog area. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in greater than 50 ppb. We resampled on 3/4/22, and again did not observe any visable cyanobacteria. The 3/4/22 sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in a non-detect. The original sample from 3/1/22 was retested, using Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in a non-detect. The discrepancy in this weeks 3/1/22 Shadow Cliffs Arroyo sample is possibly due to sampler, operator, or equipment error.
On 2/17/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the popular dog area.

On 2/7/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the popular dog area.

On 2/2/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the popular dog area.

On 1/26/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the popular dog area. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.38 ppb.

IncidentInformation:
East Bay Regional Park District conducts routine cyanobacteria bloom monitoring at this lake or shoreline location. For more info, go to: https://www.ebparks.org/about/stewardship/water/cyanobacteria_(blue_green_algae)_updates.htm

Routine monitoring results are provided below:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
4/7/22: On 4/5/22, specks and clumps of Aphanizomenon-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column from the boat launch to the dam. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect. Caution advisory recommended.

3/25/22: On 3/24/22,  specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column from the boat launch to the dam. A sample from near the oxygen buoys by the dam was tested for Microcystin, using an Abraxis strip test kit, resulting in a non-detect. 

3/18/22: On 3/15/22,  very few specks of Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the boat launch. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystin, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.03 ppb. 

3/10/22: On 3/10/22,  high winds made cyanobacteria observation difficult. No cyanobacteria were observed. 

3/4/22: On 3/2/22,  a few specks of Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the boat launch. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.07 ppb. 

2/28/22: On 2/22/22, high winds made observation difficult this week. Though a specks were observed throughout the reservoir, none were captured in the sample so species identification could not be confirmed.  

2/18/22: On 2/14/22,  a few specks of Microcystis-type and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended in the water column at the boat launch. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.32 ppb. 

2/11/22: On 2/8/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the boat launch. 

2/4/22: On 2/3/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the boat launch.

1/28/22: On 1/26/22 very few specks of Aphanizomenon-type cyanobacteria were observed at the boat launch. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAA, resulting in 0.06 ppb

On 1/20/22 very few specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed at the boat launch. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAA, resulting in a non-detect. Cautionary signage has been taken down around the lake.

On 1/11/22, windy conditions made cyanobacteria observation difficult. Very few specks Microcystis-type and Pseudoanabaena-type cyanobacteria were observed at the boat launch. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Test Strip Kits, resulting in a non-detect.

On 1/5/22, very few specks of Aphanizomenon-type and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed throughout the lake from the boat launch to the dam. A sample from the substrate sampler buoy near the dam was taken and tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Test Strip Kits, resulting in a non-detect.

On 12/9/21, green specks were collected at the boat launch, but no cyanobacteria were observed under the microscope, and no cyanobacteria were observed along the east shoreline. A sample from the boat launch was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in a non-detect.

IncidentInformation:
East Bay Regional Park District conducts routine cyanobacteria bloom monitoring at this lake or shoreline location. This lake is currently closed to swimming due to Shelter in Place mandate. For more info, go to: https://www.ebparks.org/about/stewardship/water/cyanobacteria_(blue_green_algae)_updates.htm
Routine monitoring results are provided below:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On 3/28/22, no cyanobacteria were observed at the north buoy. Azolla fern was observed covering approximately 98% of the surface of the lake.

On 3/21/22, no cyanobacteria were observed at the dam. Azolla fern was observed covering approximately 98% of the surface of the lake.

On 3/16/22, no cyanobacteria were observed at the dam. Azolla fern was observed covering approximately 90% of the surface of the lake.
On 3/9/22, no cyanobacteria were observed at the dam. Azolla fern was observed covering approximately 90% of the surface of the lake.

On 2/28/22, one small clump of Microcystis-type cyanobacteria was observed under the microscope from a sample taken at the north buoy. The sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in 0.07 ppb.

On 2/22/22, no cyanobacteria were observed throughout the lake. Azolla was observed covering approximately 75% of the lakes surface.

On 2/15/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the dam.

On 2/8/22, no visible cyanobacteria were at the dam. Azolla and duckweed were observed covering approximately a third of the lake.

On 1/31/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed throughout the lake from the swim beach to the creek inlet. Azolla and duckweed were observed covering approximately 1/6th of the lake.

On 1/24/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the dam or at the stream near Brook Picnic Area.

On 1/11/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed at the north buoy.

On 12/29/21, this weeks storms stirred up sediment around the lake, making cyanobacteria observation difficult. No visible cyanobacteria were observed near the woodbridge, at the north buoy, or at the swim beach.

12/10/21: All Lake Anza cyanobacteria advisories were removed.

On 12/8/21, the waters of Lake Anza were dark colored, and there is duckweed and Azolla fern clustered along the dam face, the east shore and creating swirls throughout the lake, but no cyanobacteria was visible in the water column. On 12/10/21, no cyanobacteria were observed at the dam or swim beach. A sample from the swim beach was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in a non-detect. Advisory removal pending.

On 11/29/21, the waters of Lake Anza were still brown. No visible cyanobacteria were observed.

12/31/2021: sample was collected on 12/22. Anatoxin-a detected at 0.18 ug/L. Caution advisory recommended. 

12/9/21: Samples were taken on 12/2/21 and the results indicate that no toxins are present. Caution is still advised due to the detection of a cyanobacteria species that has the ability to produce the toxin microcystin, the presence of algae on the beach, and the high level of recreational use by visitors and potentially dogs. 

11/3/2021: Regional Water Board staff collected a sample on 10/19. Anatoxin-a was detected at 0.17 ug/L. Caution advisory recommended. 

10/14/2021: Regional Water Board staff collected a sample on 10/7. Anatoxin-a was detected at 0.23 ug/L. Caution advisory recommended.

4/1/22: On 3/28/22, no cyanobacteria were observed at the rocks around the fishing pier.

3/18/22: On 3/15/22, we sampled algae growing on the rocks around the fishing pier. While most of the sample was filamentous algae, Microcoleus-type or Phormidium-type cyanobacteria were observed as well. A sample from the fishing pier rocks was tested for Microcystin, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect.

3/10/22: On 3/7/22, no cyanobacteria were observed in the rocks around the fishing pier.

3/4/22: On 3/2/22, no cyanobacteria were observed in the rocks around the fishing pier.

2/28/22: On 2/22/22, no cyanobacteria were observed in the rocks around the fishing pier.

2/18/22: On 2/14/22, one speck of Microcystis-type cyanobacteria was observed around the fishing pier. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS,  resulting in 0.01 ppb.

2/11/22: On 2/8/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed around the fishing pier. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS,  resulting in a non-detect.

2/4/22: On 2/3/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed around the fishing pier.

1/21/22: On 1/20/22, no visible cyanobacteria were observed around the fishing pier. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in a non-detect.

East Bay Regional Park District conducts routine cyanobacteria bloom monitoring at this lake or shoreline location. For more info, go to: https://www.ebparks.org/about/stewardship/water/cyanobacteria_(blue_green_algae)_updates.htm
Routine monitoring results are provided below:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On 4/4/22, green surface level swirls and suspended specks and clumps of Microcystis-type, Dolichospermum-type, Woronichinia-type, and Aphanizomenon-type cyanobacteria were observed at the marina.

On 3/23/22, specks and various sized clumps of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, Microcystis-type, and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed densely suspended throughout the water column at the marina. Surface level swirls, specks, and various sized clumps of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, Microcystis-type, and Woronichinia-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at bass cove. Two samples from bass cove were tested for Microcystin, using Abraxis CAAS. The first was from an area of high-density bloom, which resulted in greater than 50 ppb. The second was from less than a foot away in a low-density bloom area, which resulted in 6.91 ppb.
On 3/14/22, specks and various sized clumps of Aphanizomenon-type, Microcystis-type, Woronichinia-type, and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed densely suspended throughout the water column at the marina. A sample from the marina was tested for Microcystin, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in greater than 50 ppb
On 3/9/22, mats of scum, specks, and various sized clumps of Aphanizomenon-type, Microcystis-type, Woronichinia-type, and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed densely suspended throughout the water column at the marina.

On 3/1/22, mats of scum, specks, and various sized clumps of Aphanizomenon-type, Microcystis-type, Woronichinia-type, and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed densely suspended throughout the water column at the marina. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in greater than 50 ppb.
On 2/15/22, various sized clumps of Aphanizomenon-type, Microcystis-type, Woronichinia-type, and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed densely suspended throughout the water column at the marina. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in greater than 50 ppb.

On 2/4/22: Due to water testing results, the recommended advisory level is Danger. Observations: specks and dime-sized clumps of Microcystis-type, Woronichinia-type, Aphanizomenon-type, and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the marina. Specks, clumps, and a small patch of dense pea-soup consistency Microcystis-type, Woronichinia-type, Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Limnoraphis-type cyanobacteria were observed at bass cove. Two samples were taken at both the marina and bass cove, one at an area with a high density of cyanobacteria, and another adjacent sample at an area with a low density of cyanobacteria. The high density sample from the marina was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kit diluted at a 1:1 ratio, resulting in greater than 20 ppb. The low density sample from the marina was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in 5 ppb. Both samples were retested, using the Abraxis CAAS, resulting in greater than 50 ppb and a non-detect respectively. The high density sample from bass cove was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kit diluted at a 1:1 ratio, resulting in greater than 20 ppb. The low density sample from bass cove was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis Strip Test Kit, resulting in greater than 10 ppb. Both samples were retested, using the Abraxis CAAS, resulting in greater than 50 ppb and 13.62 ppb respectively.

On 1/25/22, scum, dense clumps, and specks of Woronichinia-type, Aphanizomenon-type, and Dolichospermum-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column and floating along the surface at the marina. A sample was tested for Microcystins, using Abraxis CAAS, resulting in greater than 50 ppb.

On 1/4/22, dime-sized and smaller clumps of Aphanizomenon-type, Dolichospermum-type, and Microcystis-type cyanobacteria were observed suspended throughout the water column at the marina.

12/13/2021: Samples were collected on 11/19 for lab analysis. Microcystins were present in the sample at a concentration of 2.12 ug/L. Caution advisory recommended.

7/8/2021: Samples were collected on 6/30 for lab analysis. Microcystins were present in the sample that exceeded warning trigger level. Warning advisory recommended.

WaterBodyName: Hensley Lake at East Floating Dock
IncidentInformation:
Central Valley Regional Board is conducting a monitoring project at Hensley Lake. The results of the HAB monitoring are provided below. For any questions contact cyanoHAB.reports@waterboards.ca.gov. 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
4/1/2022: Water was sampled on 3/21/2022 by Central Valley Regional Water Quality Board staff.  This sample contained a moderate amount of Woronichinia sp. and a low amount of Aphanizomenon. Awaiting cyanotoxin results. Warning advisory still recommended.


2/9/22: Water Boards staff collected a water sample at this site on 1/24. Water testing detected 12.0 ug/L microcystins. Warning advisory recommended.

2/4/22: lab micorscopy confirmed woronichinia and aphanizomenon sp. Caution advisory. 

1/24/22: Waterboard staff observed abundant floating colonies < 1 cm in diameter, green and murky water, and some surface scum samples on 1/24. Samples were collected and sent to a laboratory for analysis. Caution advisory recommended based on visual observation.
OfficialWaterBodyName: Hensley Lake at East Floating Dock

IncidentInformation:
2/25/2022: The Water Boards an update from partners at CA Department of Fish and Wildlife that on 2/15 , there were visual observations of a bloom on the east end of the reservoir. Photo documentation was provided that confirmed a bloom. Caution advisory is recommended.

1/26/2022: The Water Boards received a bloom report from partners at CA Department of Fish and Wildlife that on 1/18 , there were visual observations of a bloom on the east end of the reservoir. Photo documentation was provided that confirmed a bloom. Caution advisory is recommended.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------

4/1/2022: Water was sampled on 3/22/2022 by Central Valley Regional Water Quality Board staff. This sample contained a moderate amount of Dolichospermum sp. and a very low amount of Aphanizomenon. Awaiting cyanotoxin results. Caution advisory still recommended.

2/9/2022: Water was sampled on 1/25/222 by Central Valley Regional Water Quality Board staff. Lab did not detect cyanotoxins though potentially toxigenic cyanobacteria were observed. Caution advisory.

2/4/2022: lab microscopy confirmed aphanizomenon and dolichospermum. Caution advisory.

1/26/2022: Waterboard staff observed  Aphamezomenon colonies in the water column and at the surface on 1/25. Samples were collected and sent to a laboratory for analysis. Caution advisory recommended based on visual observation.

WaterBodyName: Lake in Greenhill Gated estates - near Laguna and Lakeshore.  South ave 26 and east 99
IncidentInformation:
2/2/22: The lake was chemically treated for cyanobacteria in January. Results from samples taken 1/26/22 showed Cylindrospermopsin at 0.11 ug/L and Microcystin/Nod. at 3.44 ug/L. This sample contained a moderately low amount of Microcystis sp., a low amount of Dolichospermum sp. and a very low amount of Woronichinia sp. Caution advisory recommended.

11/24/21: Golf Course staff sampled this area on 11/17. Results showed that the Microcystin concentration was 2,206.9 ug/L, the Cylindrospermopsin concentration was 0.16 ug/L and the Saxitoxin concentration was 0.10 ug/L. Danger advisory recommended.
OfficialWaterBodyName: Lake in Greenhill Gated Estates near Laguna Dr. and Lakeshore Dr.

WaterBodyName: Lake Tahoe Inlet at Skylandia Beach
IncidentInformation:
2/15/21 - Sample results indicate only eukaryotic algae present, no cyanobacteria or toxins are present.

2/8/22 - The creek is ponding prior to entrance into Lake Tahoe and algae is forming in the pond. Algae appears filamentous, but samples were taken on 2/8/22 and results are pending. Caution and general awareness signs are posted while we wait for results.

IncidentInformation: Extensive algal mats observed at site, water testing results were above Caution advisory level. Recommend posting Caution advisory signs.

WaterBodyManager:
Patrick Cory Boyd, Water Production Superintendant
City of San Diego
IncidentInformation:
2/25/2022: Water grab sample collected on 2/16 contained moderate amounts of Dolichospermum sp. and Woronichinia sp., a low amount of Microcystis sp., and very low amounts of Limnoraphis sp. and Aphanizomenon sp. Microcystins, Saxitoxins and Anatoxins were non-detect. Cylindrospermopsin was detected at 0.07 ug/L. No advisory.

2/16/2022: Due to satellite notifications, Water Board staff visited the reservoir and collected a sample for species ID and toxin analyses.

3/11/2022: The Illness Work Group has determined that the  illness reported on 2/21 was not HAB-related. No advisory recommended. 

3/8/2022: Water Boards received results from sampling on 2/28. Cyanobacteria and cyanotoxins were not detected. Results from illness investigation are pending. 

2/28/2022: Water Boards received a report of a potential human illness that occurred on 2/21. Water Boards staff visited the park and did not observe any cyanobacterial blooms in the ponds or creek. A water sample was collected near the fishing dock to determine if any cyanotoxins were present. Results are pending. A CAUTION is recommended due to suspected illness.

IncidentInformation: 3/7/2022: Sample collected on 2/28 contained low amounts of Anabaena sp. and Microcoleus sp. All toxins were non-detect. No advisory. Will re-visit during warmer weather.

IncidentInformation: 3/22/2022: The Water Boards received a report of a potential algal bloom at the Hot Spot near The Sea Ranch Association. Based on photo evidence, the observed growth was determined to be harmless green algae. No advisory recommended.
OfficialWaterBodyName: South Fork Gualala River at the Sea Ranch Hot Spot

IncidentInformation: 3/29/22: A sample was collected by a Waterboard volunteer at the end of the boat ramp dock at about 10 ft depth on 3/17/22. A greenish-brown layer could be seen covering the rocks on the bottom.  Microscopic ID of a benthic sample showed that the material was predominantly made up of cyanobacteria from the Oscillatoriales family (probably Phormidium). Caution avdisory recommended.

Results from the 3/29/22 sample event show eukaryotic algae only. No toxins are present.

Bloom appears to be the typical periphyton seen in Lake Tahoe this time of year, but samples were taken as a precaution.
